OBJECT #001 Suspected paperweight, possibly decorative, possibly load-bearing for someone's sanity. Recovered from Cubicle 14-D, 2nd floor, a building in Secaucus whose name no one remembers because the sign fell off in 2019. Surface: smooth. Interior: unknowable. The resin preserved a post-it that reads "call Dan re: the thing." Dan was never called. The thing remains unresolved.

The Disposable Years Left Things Behind

ResinRepos is not a store. It's a recovery operation. We enter buildings after the last box has been carried out and the keycards have been deactivated, and we find what was left behind: desk ornaments nobody claimed, coffee mugs with passive-aggressive slogans, a stress ball shaped like a brain that someone squeezed through four reorgs and two acquisitions.

We pour resin over these objects. Not to preserve them — to admit they existed. Every object on this site was produced by accident in a place that was trying to produce quarterly reports. The fluorescent lights made everything ugly, and then someone left, and the ugly things became the only honest record of what happened there.

I spent four years as a Macro-Level Data Synergy Analyst. I still don't know what that means. But I know what my desk looked like at 6:47pm on a Wednesday in November, and I know the objects that were on it, and I know that they mattered more than anything I was asked to deliver.

Barnaby is at sea. Esme makes toast now.

The warehouse is in a strip mall between a nail salon and a place that sells replacement hot tub covers. We are open by appointment. The appointment system is an email that says "when." We reply with a time. It's the most functional process either of us has ever been part of.
